description: several people in coats, boots, and carrying umbrellas, walking along a snow covered sidewalk--two walking away, two walking towards viewer, and two in distance--while heavy snow continues to fall; apartment building stoops/stairs along right side of image; a sign, trash cans, and street light along street on left
medium: Drypoint and sandpaper ground etching on pale green paper
provenance: Private collection, Washington, D.C.; (William P. Carl Fine Prints, Durham, N.C); sold to MIA, 2019.
signed: Signed in pencil, LR margin: Martin Lewis  |  signed within the plate, LLC: MARTIN LEWIS
text: Published in 1930, Stoops in Snow is a tour-de-force of Lewis’s intaglio printmaking oeuvre, a perfect balance of compositional originality and technical virtuosity. Depicting an ephemeral moment in the life of the city, the scene features several men and women walking beside a row of brownstones, heads bowed, bundled against the driving wind, cold, and snow of a New York blizzard. As in many of Lewis’s urban scenes, people and architecture are its principal subjects, but here the print’s aesthetic and conceptual qualities largely derive from the pictorial effects of light and weather conditions. Lewis’s masterful interpretation of wind driven snow accumulating on the city’s streets, sidewalks, and open-air stairs plays on the viewer’s memory and recognition to convey the raw sensations of a winter storm. Additionally, there is an unmistakable air of mystery in the scene’s fleeting activity, a sense that the city is alive with stories large and small, mostly hidden from view.
title: Stoops in Snow
